Description: Rectangular terracotta (pottery) stamp probably with a loop handle on the back, the points of attachment are all that now remain. The front face is incised with a three line inscription in Greek. Pink marl clay with a thick grey core and an overall brown slip.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Qasr Ibrim (Nubia), house LC2-1 floor 3
Curator's comments: Terracotta IV Excavation no. QI 64/82. Donated: Egypt Exploration Society. Excavated at Qasr Ibrim in 1964, Context H168-F1. From a context of the Late Christian II Period, c. AD 1300-1400: the stamp may or may not be residual. Greek texts, amongst other languages, were found in Late and Terminal Christian levels (Adams 1996: 213-42). Elias is a Hebrew name, and one which was used by Christian Greeks, including writers of a religious bent during Byzantine times (Means 1876: 9-19) and presumably later, but obviously not confined to such a profession or to Greeks. Other usages of the name Arispromos have not been found. Bibliog: Adams 1996: 194-5 and 296, fig. 30:9 (not accurately rendered), pl. 58b. For mentions of House 168, see ibid.: 33, 38, 40 and 258, fig. 4.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3601)
Łajtar & van der Vliet 2010 / Qasr Ibrim: The Greek and Coptic inscriptions (no.17)
Acquisition name: Division of Finds: Egyptian Antiquities Organisation
